title: Gardening — Planting Seeds Indoors
description: The child prepares small pots with soil and plants seeds to observe germination. This introduces the life cycle of plants through direct, hands-on experience and builds responsibility through daily watering.
instructions:
1. Gather materials on a tray: small pots, potting soil, seeds (bean or sunflower), watering can, labels, pencil.
2. Demonstrate filling a pot with soil to about 1 inch from the top, pressing gently.
3. Make a small hole with your finger (about 1 inch deep for beans).
4. Place one seed in the hole and cover gently with soil.
5. Write the seed name and date on a label. Place in the pot.
6. Water gently — 'Just enough to make the soil damp, not soggy.'
7. Place pots near a sunny window.
8. Discuss: 'What do seeds need to grow? Sun, water, and soil.'
materials_needed: Small pots or recycled containers with drainage holes
Newspaper or mat for the work surface

slides.heading: Gardening
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! We're going to be gardeners today and plant some seeds right inside our house. It's going to be so exciting to watch them grow!

slides.setup_instructions: Cover work surface with newspaper. Arrange all materials on a tray from left to right in order of use.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need to be super gardeners! We have little pots, soft dirt called potting soil, tiny seeds that will grow into plants, a little watering can to give them a drink, and some sticks to write on. Let's ask a grown-up to help us gather all these special things onto our tray!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to plant seeds! Seeds are tiny, but they have everything they need inside to become a whole plant.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is the day we get to be plant planters! We're going to put these little seeds into the dirt, and they have a secret power inside them to grow into big, tall plants all by themselves. It's like magic!

slides.text: Demonstrate filling the pot with soil: 'Scoop the soil gently. Fill the pot to about here — leave room at the top so water doesn't overflow.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's fill our little pot with this soft, brown soil. We want to fill it up, but not all the way to the tippy-top, so there's a little room left for our plant to grow and for water. Gently pat it down, like patting a sleepy puppy.

slides.text: 'Now make a little hole with your finger, about this deep.' Show one inch. 'Place ONE seed inside and cover it gently with soil, like tucking it into bed.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to make a cozy little bed for our seed! Use your finger to make a small hole in the dirt, just deep enough for the seed to hide. Then, carefully put one seed in and cover it up with a little bit of soil, like tucking it in for a nap.

slides.text: 'Write the name of your seed on the label. Write today's date too — we want to know when we planted it!' Place the label in the pot.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need to remember which seed is which and when we planted it! Let's use the pencil to write the name of our seed and today's date on this little stick, and then we'll put it right in the pot so we know.

slides.text: 'Water very gently — just a little bit. The soil should be damp, not a puddle. Seeds can drown if there's too much water!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Shhh, don't give our seed too much to drink! We'll use our watering can to give it just a tiny sip of water. We want the dirt to feel a little bit wet, like a damp sponge, but not like a big puddle.

slides.prompt: Plant 2-3 seeds in separate pots. Label each one. Place them near a sunny window. Draw a picture in your journal of what you planted today.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! Now let's put our little pots in a super sunny spot, like right by the window where the sunbeams play. We'll draw a picture of our seeds and the pots, and remember to check on them every day!

slides.text: Clean up: sweep any spilled soil, wash hands, put away materials. 'Starting tomorrow, check your seeds each day. Water when the soil feels dry on top.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently fill a pot, plant a seed at the correct depth, and water appropriately?
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job planting our seeds! Now, let's tidy up our gardening space by sweeping up any extra dirt and washing our hands. Starting tomorrow, we'll check our seeds to see if they need a drink of water, and we'll watch them grow bigger and bigger!

parent_notes: Gardening is a cornerstone Montessori practical life activity that develops patience, responsibility, and scientific observation. Bean seeds germinate quickly (5-7 days) making them ideal for young children who need to see results. Sunflower seeds take a bit longer but are exciting because the plants grow large. This begins a multi-week project: the child will water daily, observe changes, and eventually transplant outdoors. Consider starting a simple garden journal where the child draws observations. Maria Montessori believed that caring for living things develops the child's sense of responsibility and connection to the natural world.

title: Long Vowel Patterns — Silent E (a_e)
description: Introduction to the 'magic e' or 'silent e' pattern where adding an e to the end of a CVC word changes the short vowel to a long vowel. Focuses on the a_e pattern: cap/cape, tap/tape, mat/mate.
instructions:
1. Write 'cap' on a card. Child reads it: /k/-/a/-/p/ = cap.
2. 'Watch what happens when I add a letter.' Place an 'e' at the end: cape.
3. 'The e is magic! It doesn't say anything itself, but it reaches over and changes the /a/ to say its NAME: /ay/. Cap becomes CAPE!'
4. Practice pairs: tap/tape, mat/mate, can/cane, pan/pane, hat/hate, man/mane.
5. Child reads each pair, noting the vowel change.
6. Build a_e words with moveable alphabet: lake, bake, cake, make, game, name, came, same.
materials_needed: Paper and pencil for writing practice

slides.heading: The Magic E
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! It shows us we're going to learn about "magic e" and how it makes special "long a" words, like the ones that have "a_e" in them.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word pairs on cards (cap/cape, tap/tape, etc.) or have a whiteboard ready. Set out the moveable alphabet.
slides.mascot_explanation: We'll use some special letter pieces called a moveable alphabet, and some word cards, and a special mat for our work. Ask a grown-up to help you find these things so we can play and learn together!

slides.text: 'You know how to read short vowel words like cap, tap, and mat. Today you'll learn a magic trick that letters can do!'
slides.mascot_explanation: You already know how to read words with a short "a" sound, like "cap" or "tap." Today, we're going to learn a super cool trick that makes those words say their names!

slides.text: Build 'cap' with the moveable alphabet. 'Read this word.' Then add 'e' to the end. 'The e is SILENT — it doesn't make a sound. But it's magic!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's build the word "cap" with our letter pieces. Now, watch this! We're going to put a letter "e" right at the end. This "e" is super quiet – it doesn't make a sound at all!

slides.text: 'The magic e reaches back over the consonant and taps the vowel, making it say its NAME instead of its sound. /a/ becomes /ay/. Cap becomes CAPE!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This quiet "e" is like a little helper! It reaches back and tells the "a" to say its name, "ay," instead of its short sound, "a." So "cap" magically turns into "cape"!

slides.text: Practice more pairs: tap/tape, mat/mate, can/cane, pan/pane. 'The e changes every short a to a long a!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We can do this with other words too! We'll practice saying "tap" and then "tape," and "mat" and then "mate." It's like the magic "e" gives the "a" a little tap to say "ay"!

slides.prompt: Build these words with the moveable alphabet: lake, bake, cake, game, name, came, save, wave. Read each one aloud.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to build some more magic words with our letter pieces! Can you make "lake," "bake," and "cake"? Say each word out loud – you're doing so great!

slides.text: 'Now you know the magic e rule! When you see a vowel-consonant-e at the end of a word, the vowel says its name.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 6 a_e words and explain that the silent e makes the vowel 'say its name'?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned how the magic "e" helps the "a" say its name! Now you know how to read lots of new words, like "lake" and "cake"!

parent_notes: The silent e (or 'magic e') pattern is one of the most important phonics rules in English. In Montessori, we often present this as a sensorial discovery: the child sees and hears the transformation from short to long vowel. The key concept is that the e is silent but changes the preceding vowel from its short sound to its long sound (its letter name). Start with a_e this week and introduce i_e and o_e in subsequent lessons. Some children grasp this immediately; others need many repetitions with the word pairs. Using the moveable alphabet lets them physically add and remove the e to see the transformation.

title: Stamp Game — Multiplication Introduction
description: Introduction to multiplication using the stamp game. The child learns that multiplication means 'taking the same number many times' by building repeated groups and combining them.
instructions:
1. 'We're going to learn something new today: multiplication! Multiplication means taking the same number MANY times.'
2. 'Let's try 3 taken 2 times. That means we make the number 3 TWO times.'
3. On the stamp game board, build 3 (three green unit stamps) in the first row.
4. Build 3 again in the second row.
5. 'Now count all the stamps together: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6! 3 taken 2 times equals 6.'
6. Practice: 4 taken 2 times, 2 taken 3 times, 5 taken 2 times.
7. Introduce the multiplication sign: 3 x 2 = 6.
materials_needed: Small paper strips for writing equations

slides.heading: Stamp Game Multiplication
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we're going to learn about something super cool called multiplication! It's like a magic trick for adding numbers really fast.

items: Stamp game with stamps and board
slides.setup_instructions: Set out the stamp game on the mat. Have paper ready for writing equations.
slides.mascot_explanation: To play our multiplication game, we need some special friends! We need our stamp game with lots of little stamps and a special board to put them on. We also need a mat to keep our table clean and some paper and a pencil for writing down our number secrets. Ask a grown-up to help you find them all!

slides.text: 'You already know addition — putting numbers together. Multiplication is a SPECIAL kind of addition. It means taking the SAME number again and again!'
slides.mascot_explanation: You already know how to add, right? That's like putting toys together. Well, multiplication is like adding the *same* toy over and over again, super quickly!

slides.text: '3 taken 2 times: make a group of 3 green stamps. Now make ANOTHER group of 3 green stamps right below it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try a fun one! We're going to take the number 3, and we're going to do it two times. So, let's put three green stamps here, and then right below it, let's make another group of three green stamps.

slides.text: 'How many do we have altogether? Count them all!' Child counts: 6. 'So 3 taken 2 times is 6! We write it: 3 x 2 = 6.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! We made our groups! Now, let's count all the stamps together. One, two, three, four, five, six! So, 3 taken 2 times makes 6. We can write that like this: 3 x 2 = 6. Isn't that neat?

slides.text: 'The x means TIMES — how many times we take that number. Let's try 4 taken 2 times.' Build two rows of 4 stamps.
slides.mascot_explanation: That little 'x' sign is like a secret code that means "times"! It tells us how many times we take a number. Let's try another one: 4 taken 2 times. Can you make two rows with four stamps in each?

slides.prompt: Use the stamp game to solve: 2 x 3, 5 x 2, 4 x 3, 3 x 3. Build each group, count the total, and write the equation on paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the multiplication expert! We're going to use our stamps to figure out some problems. Try to make the groups, count them all up, and then write down the number sentence, just like we practiced. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Multiplication is really fast addition! Instead of 3 + 3, we can say 3 x 2. You'll see — multiplication is very powerful!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build repeated groups with stamps and count the total for at least 3 multiplication problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a multiplication superstar! You learned that instead of adding the same number lots of times, we can use multiplication to do it super fast. Remember how you made all those groups of stamps? That's how you do multiplication!

parent_notes: Montessori introduces multiplication concretely before any memorization of facts. The stamp game makes multiplication visible: the child physically builds identical groups and counts the result. The language 'taken X times' is traditional Montessori phrasing and helps the child understand what the operation means. At this stage, keep multiplicands small (2-5) and multipliers small (2-3) so the child can count the result easily. Do not rush to the times tables — deep understanding of the concept comes first. The child should see that 3 x 2 means 'make 3, two times' and then count to verify.

title: Spring Around the World
description: Exploring how spring looks different in various parts of the world. The child learns that while it is spring in the Northern Hemisphere, it is autumn in the Southern Hemisphere, connecting to earlier globe and hemisphere work.
instructions:
1. Look at the globe together. Review: 'Remember the equator — the invisible line around the middle of Earth?'
2. 'When it is spring HERE (point to Northern Hemisphere), it is FALL on the other side (point to Southern Hemisphere).'
3. Show pictures of spring in different countries: cherry blossoms in Japan, tulips in the Netherlands, monsoon rains in India.
4. 'What does spring look like where WE live?' Discuss local signs of spring.
5. The child draws or colors a picture showing spring in two different hemispheres.
6. Label the drawings: 'Spring' and 'Autumn.'
materials_needed: Pictures of spring in different countries

slides.heading: Spring Around the World
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Spring Around the World," and it means we're going to learn how spring is different in other places, and how some places have a different season altogether!

items: Pictures of spring scenes from different countries
slides.setup_instructions: Gather pictures showing spring in at least 3 different countries. Have the globe accessible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the cool things we need for our adventure! We have a globe, which is like a little ball of our Earth, and pretty pictures of flowers and faraway places, and paper and crayons for us to draw with!

slides.text: 'It's springtime! But did you know that RIGHT NOW, on the other side of the world, it's autumn? Let's find out why!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's spring here, where we live, right? But guess what? On the other side of the world, they're getting ready for cozy autumn days! We're going to learn why that happens!

slides.text: Show the globe. 'The Earth is tilted. When our part (Northern Hemisphere) tilts toward the sun, we get spring and summer. The other side gets fall and winter!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this big ball? It's our Earth, and it's a little bit tilted! When our part is closer to the warm sun, we get spring and summer, but the other side gets cooler fall and winter.

slides.text: Show pictures: 'In Japan, spring means beautiful cherry blossoms. In the Netherlands, millions of tulips bloom. What happens where we live?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these beautiful pictures! In Japan, they have pretty pink flowers called cherry blossoms, and in the Netherlands, they have bright, colorful tulips! What does spring look like where we live?

slides.prompt: Draw two pictures side by side: spring in the Northern Hemisphere and autumn in the Southern Hemisphere. Label each drawing and the hemisphere.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be artists! We're going to draw two pictures: one showing spring where we are, and one showing autumn on the other side of the world. Then we'll write "Spring" and "Autumn" on them!

slides.text: 'The Earth is amazing — people all over the world experience different seasons at the same time!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that opposite hemispheres have opposite seasons?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You learned that when it's sunny and warm spring here, it's cool and colorful autumn somewhere else – isn't our Earth amazing? You were such a great explorer!

parent_notes: This lesson connects the child's direct experience of spring to a broader geographic understanding. Montessori education emphasizes cosmic education — helping the child see themselves as part of a larger whole. The concept that hemispheres have opposite seasons is fascinating to young children and builds on earlier work with the globe. If possible, look outside together and note signs of spring: buds on trees, longer days, warmer temperatures, birds returning. This grounds the abstract concept in the child's lived experience.

title: Read-Aloud: From Seed to Plant by Gail Gibbons
description: Reading 'From Seed to Plant' by Gail Gibbons, a clear nonfiction book explaining the life cycle of plants from seed to flower, including pollination and seed dispersal.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'We've been learning about seeds and plants. Let's learn more!'
2. Read aloud, pausing at the clear diagrams and labels.
3. Discuss each stage: seed, germination, roots, stem, leaves, flower, fruit, new seeds.
4. Point out the pollination page: 'Remember how bees help flowers?'
5. Review seed dispersal methods: wind, water, animals.
6. Connect to plants you've observed or grown.
materials_needed: From Seed to Plant by Gail Gibbons
Optional: bean seeds and wet paper towel for germination

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: From Seed to Plant by Gail Gibbons
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this beautiful book cover! It has a special name, "From Seed to Plant," and a nice picture. We are going to read this book together to learn all about how plants grow, like magic!

items: Optional: bean seeds for germination experiment
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Consider starting a germination observation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to get our special book ready! We also have some tiny bean seeds, which are like little sleeping plants. We can watch them wake up and grow if you want to!

slides.text: Cover: 'Gail Gibbons is going to teach us exactly how a tiny seed becomes a big plant. Let's follow the journey!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We are going to look at the very beginning of our book, the cover. It shows us that we're going on an adventure to learn how a little seed turns into a big plant. Let's turn the page and see!

slides.text: Read through each stage clearly. Gail Gibbons' labeled diagrams are perfect for learning plant vocabulary.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the story and look at the pictures. See how the book shows us all the different parts of a plant? We'll learn what they are called and what they do.

slides.text: Discuss: 'What does a seed need to germinate? How do seeds travel to new places? What is pollination?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to talk about some super important things today! We'll find out what a tiny seed needs to start growing, how seeds get to new places, and how buzzy bees help flowers.

slides.prompt: Draw the life cycle of a plant: seed, sprout, plant, flower, fruit, new seed. Label each stage!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an artist! Let's draw a picture of how a plant grows, starting with a seed and ending with a flower or fruit that makes new seeds. You can draw the little plant parts too!

slides.text: 'From a tiny seed to a big plant and back to seeds again — it's a circle of life!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe at least three stages of a plant's life cycle?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job learning about plants! We saw how a little seed grows into a big plant and then makes new seeds, just like a circle. You can tell me three things a plant needs to grow!

parent_notes: Gail Gibbons' nonfiction is perfectly suited to Montessori's concrete-to-abstract approach. This book provides clear scientific illustrations that complement hands-on botany work. Consider the bean germination experiment at the back of the book — watching a seed sprout in a wet paper towel is a classic Montessori activity.

title: Constructive Triangles — Exploration with Hexagonal Box
description: The child uses the hexagonal box of constructive triangles to discover that triangles can combine to form hexagons, rhombuses, and parallelograms. This deepens understanding of how shapes relate to one another.
instructions:
1. Open the hexagonal box. 'All of these pieces are triangles. Let's see what shapes we can build!'
2. Take two green triangles. Place them together along the black line: 'A rhombus!'
3. Take three red triangles. Join along black lines: 'A trapezoid!'
4. Take all six yellow triangles. Join them: 'A hexagon! Six triangles make a hexagon!'
5. Let the child experiment: 'What other shapes can you make with these triangles?'
6. Name each shape the child creates.

slides.heading: Constructive Triangles
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Constructive Triangles" and talks about a special box called the "Hexagonal Box." That means we're going to play with triangle shapes today!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the mat. Open the hexagonal box and spread the triangles out so the child can see them all.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these shapes! These are our constructive triangles, and we have a special box for them. We also have a colorful mat to put our shapes on. Can you help me find the special hexagonal box and spread out all the colorful triangles on the mat?

slides.text: 'Remember the constructive triangles? Today we have the hexagonal box. All the pieces are triangles — but watch what shapes they can make!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember those triangle shapes we've played with before? Well, this box is full of them! They all look like triangles, but let's see if we can put them together to make new, exciting shapes.

slides.text: 'Take two green triangles. Match the black lines together.' The child joins them. 'What shape did you make? A RHOMBUS — like a diamond!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's take two of the green triangles. See the black lines on them? We need to put those black lines together nice and snug. Look! When we put them together, they make a shape that looks like a diamond. We call that a rhombus!

slides.text: 'Now try three red triangles together.' Join along the black lines. 'This shape is called a TRAPEZOID!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try the red triangles. Can you take three of the red ones and put their black lines together? Poof! You made another new shape! This one is called a trapezoid. Isn't that cool how triangles can join up?

slides.text: 'Can you use ALL six yellow triangles to make one big shape?' Guide if needed. 'A HEXAGON — a shape with six sides!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super fun challenge! Can you take all six of the yellow triangles and fit them together? Wow, you did it! When you put all six yellow triangles together, they make a big shape with six sides. It's called a hexagon!

slides.prompt: Experiment freely! How many different shapes can you make by combining different triangles? Try 2, 3, 4, and 6 triangles together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a shape builder! You can try putting different numbers of triangles together to see what amazing shapes you can create. Maybe try two, or three, or even four triangles. What new shapes can you discover all by yourself?

slides.text: 'Triangles are amazing — they can build so many other shapes! Every shape you made was built from triangles.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child construct a hexagon from 6 triangles and name at least 2 shapes made from combining triangles?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a fantastic shape builder! You learned that triangles are super special because they can fit together to make bigger shapes like diamonds and hexagons. It's like a puzzle where triangles make all sorts of cool pictures!

parent_notes: The constructive triangles are a brilliant Montessori material that reveals a fundamental geometric truth: all polygons can be divided into triangles. The hexagonal box specifically shows that a hexagon is composed of 6 equilateral triangles. The black lines on the triangle edges guide the child to correct pairings. Let the child discover and experiment — if they create an unexpected shape, name it and celebrate the discovery. This work prepares for later geometry, including understanding area as a concept built from triangles.

title: Long Vowel Patterns — Silent E (i_e)
description: Extending the magic e pattern to i_e words. The child discovers that the same silent e rule applies: adding e changes the short i (/ih/) to long i (/eye/). Pairs: bit/bite, kit/kite, fin/fine, hid/hide.
instructions:
1. Review a_e: 'Remember the magic e? It makes the vowel say its name. Cap becomes cape.'
2. 'Today the magic e works on the letter i!' Write 'bit' — child reads it.
3. Add e: 'bite!' 'The short /ih/ changed to long /eye/ — i says its name!'
4. Practice pairs: kit/kite, fin/fine, hid/hide, pin/pine, dim/dime, rip/ripe.
5. Build i_e words with moveable alphabet: like, bike, hike, time, line, vine, ride, side.
6. Child reads all words aloud.

slides.heading: The Magic E
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we're going to learn about "The Magic E" and how it makes the letter "i" sound special, like in "bite" and "kite"!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word pair cards (bit/bite, kit/kite, etc.). Set out the moveable alphabet.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special learning toys ready! We have a box of letter pieces called a moveable alphabet, some cards with word pictures, a special mat to build words on, and paper and a pencil. Ask your grown-up to help you find them all!

slides.text: 'Remember the magic e from yesterday? It changed /a/ to /ay/ in words like cape and lake. Today the magic e will work on the letter i!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how yesterday the magic "e" made the "a" sound like "ay," like in "cape"? Well, today that same magic "e" is going to help the letter "i" say its name instead of its short sound!

slides.text: Build 'bit' with the moveable alphabet. Child reads: 'bit.' Add e: 'Now read it!' BITE. 'The /ih/ changed to /eye/!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's build the word "bit" with our letter pieces. Now, let's add the magic "e" to the end. Read the new word! See how "bit" changed to "bite," and the "i" now sounds like "eye"?

slides.text: More pairs: kit/kite — 'A kit is a set of tools. A kite flies in the sky!' fin/fine, hid/hide, pin/pine.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's try some more word pairs! We can make "kit" and "kite," and "fin" and "fine." It's so cool how adding just one little "e" changes the word and the sound!

slides.text: 'The magic e rule works the same way: the e is silent, but it makes the i say its name — /eye/.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So remember, when we see an "i" with an "e" at the end of a word, the "e" is quiet, but it makes the "i" say its name, like "eye"!

slides.prompt: Build these i_e words: like, bike, hike, time, line, vine, ride, side, five, nine. Read each one. Can you use 3 of them in sentences?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the word builder! Can you use your letter pieces to make words like "like," "bike," and "time"? Try to say them out loud, and maybe even make up a little sentence for three of them!

slides.text: 'Now you know TWO magic e patterns: a_e and i_e! Tomorrow we'll learn another one.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 6 i_e words and distinguish short i from long i in word pairs?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job today learning about the magic "e" with the letter "i"! You know how to make words like "kite" and "bike" now, and that's super smart!

parent_notes: Building on yesterday's a_e lesson, i_e follows the same pattern. The power of this approach is that the child discovers the RULE — not just individual words. Once they understand that silent e changes the vowel, they can decode thousands of words they have never seen before. The word pairs (bit/bite, kit/kite) make the transformation concrete and memorable. If the child confuses short and long i, go back to the pairs and emphasize the contrast. Some children enjoy the drama of the 'magic e' — you can make a little wand and have them 'cast the spell' on each word!

title: Introduction to Skip Counting Chains — Chain of 2
description: The child uses the short bead chain of 2 to count by twos. Each bead bar has 2 beads, and the child places number arrows at each bar to build the skip counting sequence: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10...
instructions:
1. Bring out the short chain of 2 (five bars of 2 beads connected by links).
2. Lay the chain in a straight line on the mat.
3. 'Each bar has 2 beads. Let's count by 2s!' Touch the end of each bar: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10.
4. Place the number arrow '2' at the end of the first bar, '4' at the second, and so on.
5. 'We call this skip counting — we skip a number each time: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10!'
6. Remove the arrows. Child places them independently.
7. Count the chain forward and backward.

slides.heading: Bead Chain Counting
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! This is our special math lesson today. We're going to learn a super fun way to count, called skip counting!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out a long floor mat. Have the chain and arrows ready in a cup or small box.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special things ready! We have a long chain made of little bars, and each bar has two beads. We also have some number cards with numbers on them. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these?

slides.text: 'This is the chain of 2. Each little bar has 2 beads. Let's stretch it out on the mat in a long line!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this chain! It's like a little train of beads. Each part of the train has two beads. Let's stretch it out nice and long on our special mat so we can see it all.

slides.text: 'Let's count by 2s. Touch the end of each bar with me: 2... 4... 6... 8... 10!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to count these beads in a special way! Put your finger on the end of the first part and say "2". Then move to the next part and say "4". Keep going all the way to the end – 6, 8, 10!

slides.text: 'Now let's mark each count with an arrow.' Place the arrow labeled '2' after the first bar, '4' after the second, and so on.
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job counting! Now, let's put our number cards in the right spots. We put the "2" card after the first two beads, the "4" card after the next two, and so on. It's like giving each group of two beads its number name.

slides.text: 'Look at the pattern: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10. We skipped all the odd numbers! This is called SKIP COUNTING.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See how we jumped from 2 to 4, then to 6? We skipped the numbers in between! This is called skip counting, and it's a fast way to count groups of things, like pairs of shoes!

slides.prompt: Remove all the arrows. Now YOU place them at the right spots! Count by 2s as you go. Then try counting backward: 10, 8, 6, 4, 2!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the teacher! Take all the number cards off the chain. Can you put them back in the right place all by yourself? Count with me as you go: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10! Now try counting backward, like a rocket ship coming down!

slides.text: 'You can count by 2s! This is also connected to multiplication — 2 taken 5 times is 10, just like our chain!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child place all number arrows correctly on the chain of 2 and recite the skip counting sequence?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You can skip count by 2s all by yourself! You even learned that when we count by 2s five times, it's like having 10 things. You are such a super math star!

parent_notes: The bead chains are one of Montessori's most elegant math materials. The chain of 2 physically shows what skip counting means — the child touches and counts real beads. This concrete experience builds the foundation for multiplication tables later. The number arrows help the child see the pattern visually. Once the chain is laid out with all arrows, the child can see the entire skip counting sequence at a glance. Counting backward (10, 8, 6, 4, 2) is also important — it prepares for subtraction and division. Let the child work with this chain many times; repetition builds fluency.

title: Life Cycle of a Butterfly — Egg and Caterpillar Stages
description: Beginning a multi-lesson exploration of the butterfly life cycle. Today focuses on the first two stages: egg and caterpillar (larva). The child learns that butterflies begin as tiny eggs on leaves and hatch into hungry caterpillars.
instructions:
1. 'Today we begin learning about one of nature's most amazing transformations — how a butterfly is born!'
2. Show a picture or model of a butterfly egg on a leaf. 'A butterfly lays tiny, tiny eggs on leaves. Each egg is smaller than a grain of rice!'
3. 'Inside the egg, a caterpillar is growing. When it's ready, it hatches!' Show image of a tiny caterpillar.
4. 'The caterpillar's job is to EAT. It eats leaves all day long and grows bigger and bigger.'
5. 'As it grows, its skin gets too tight. It molts — sheds its old skin — and has a new, bigger skin underneath!'
6. Child draws the egg stage and caterpillar stage in their science journal.
7. Label: 'Egg' and 'Caterpillar (Larva).'
materials_needed: Pictures of butterfly eggs and caterpillars
Butterfly life cycle model or chart (optional)

slides.heading: Life Cycle of a Butterfly
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the title! Today we're going to learn about something super cool: how a butterfly is made! It's like magic, but it's real!

items: Pictures of butterfly eggs and caterpillars
slides.setup_instructions: Gather pictures showing butterfly eggs (close-up) and caterpillars at different sizes. If you have a butterfly garden kit, this is the time to start it!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special tools ready for our butterfly adventure! We have pictures of teeny-tiny butterfly eggs and wiggly caterpillars. We also have a chart to help us remember, and our special science journal with crayons to draw in. Can you help ask a grown-up to find these for us?

slides.text: 'Butterflies are so beautiful, but they don't start out that way! They go through an amazing change. Let's find out how it begins.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the very beginning of our story! Butterflies start as something super tiny, and then they change a lot. We're going to learn all about their amazing journey!

slides.text: 'A mother butterfly lays tiny eggs on a leaf. Look at this picture — the eggs are SO small! Inside each egg, a caterpillar is growing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look closely at this picture! See that little speck on the leaf? That's a butterfly egg, and it's so small, smaller than even a sprinkle! Inside that tiny egg, a little caterpillar is getting ready to come out.

slides.text: 'When the egg hatches, out comes a tiny caterpillar! What do you think the caterpillar does? It EATS! It eats and eats and grows and grows.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Pop! Out of the egg comes a little caterpillar! And guess what its most important job is? Eating! This little caterpillar will munch on leaves all day long to get bigger and bigger.

slides.text: 'The caterpillar grows so much that it has to shed its skin — like taking off a shirt that's too small! This is called molting.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no, the caterpillar is growing so fast! Its skin is getting too tight, like when your favorite shirt feels too small. So, it wiggles out of its old skin, and underneath is a new, bigger skin!

slides.prompt: In your science journal, draw the first two stages: 1) A tiny egg on a leaf, 2) A caterpillar eating leaves. Label each stage.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an artist! In your science journal, let's draw a tiny egg on a leaf, just like we saw. Then, draw a hungry caterpillar munching on some leaves. Don't forget to write "egg" and "caterpillar" next to your drawings!

slides.text: 'We learned the first two stages: egg and caterpillar. Next time, we'll find out what happens when the caterpillar is done eating!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe what happens in the egg stage and caterpillar stage of the butterfly life cycle?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned about the first two parts of a butterfly's life: the egg and the hungry caterpillar that hatches out. Next time, we'll find out what happens after the caterpillar eats so much!

parent_notes: The butterfly life cycle is a quintessential Montessori science study because it demonstrates metamorphosis — complete transformation — in a way children can observe directly. If possible, order a butterfly garden kit (painted lady butterflies) so the child can watch the entire process over 3-4 weeks. The caterpillar stage fascinates children: it eats constantly and molts several times. Connecting this to the child's own growth ('You've outgrown clothes too!') makes it relatable. We'll cover chrysalis and adult stages in later lessons. The science journal drawing reinforces vocabulary and sequencing.

title: Watercolor Painting — Spring Flowers
description: The child uses watercolors to paint spring flowers, practicing brush control, color mixing, and creative expression. This connects to the gardening and nature themes of the week.
instructions:
1. Set up watercolor station: paper, watercolors, water cup, brush, paper towels.
2. 'Today we are going to paint spring flowers! What flowers do you know?'
3. Demonstrate: wet the brush, touch one color, paint a simple petal shape on your paper.
4. 'To make different colors, you can mix! Yellow and red make orange. Yellow and blue make green.'
5. Show how to paint stems (green) and a simple flower shape.
6. 'Now you paint your own spring garden! You can use any colors you like.'
7. Let the child paint freely, offering guidance only if asked.
8. When finished, sign the painting and let it dry flat.
materials_needed: Watercolor paper or thick white paper
Mat or newspaper to protect surface

slides.heading: Watercolor Painting
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to paint pretty pictures that look like springtime flowers. It's going to be so much fun, like a colorful party for our eyes!

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the work surface. Fill the water cup. Lay out paints, paper, and brushes. Have the child put on a smock.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we need for our painting! We have the colorful paints, special paper, brushes to paint with, a cup for water, and soft paper towels to clean up. You'll also wear a special smock to keep your clothes clean, like a super artist! Ask your grown-up to help you get all these treasures ready.

slides.text: 'It's spring! Flowers are blooming everywhere. Today we will paint our own spring garden with watercolors.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray, it's springtime, and all the flowers are waking up outside! Today, we get to be artists and paint our very own garden full of beautiful flowers. What kind of flowers do you love to see?

slides.text: Demonstrate: 'Dip your brush in water, then touch the color. Paint a petal shape like this.' Show a simple oval or circle petal.
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! First, we dip our brush in the water, then we gently touch a color, like red or yellow. Then, we make a pretty shape on the paper, like a little circle or a swoosh for a petal. It's like giving the paper a colorful hug!

slides.text: 'You can mix colors! Watch: yellow and blue make GREEN for stems and leaves. Red and yellow make ORANGE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? We can make new colors, like magic! If we mix yellow and blue paint together, we get green, perfect for leaves and stems. And if we mix red and yellow, we get bright orange! It's like being a color chef!

slides.text: 'Paint your own spring garden. Flowers can be any shape and any color you imagine!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make your own special garden! You can make flowers any shape you want, and any color you can imagine. Maybe you'll make purple flowers or blue flowers – anything is possible!

slides.prompt: Paint a spring garden with at least 3 different flowers. Try mixing colors to create new ones. Add stems, leaves, and maybe a sun or butterfly!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make your amazing garden! Try to paint at least three different flowers, and don't forget to mix some colors to make new ones. You can add green stems and leaves, and maybe even a happy sun or a little butterfly flying by. You've got this!

slides.text: Sign your painting with your name. Clean your brushes by swirling in water and drying with a paper towel. Let the painting dry flat.
slides.mastery_check: Did the child use watercolor techniques (wetting brush, mixing colors, brush control) to create a painting?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job painting your garden! Let's write your name on your beautiful picture so everyone knows it's yours. We'll swish the brushes in the water and dry them off, and then we'll let your artwork dry flat. You were so good at mixing colors and making those pretty flowers!

parent_notes: Montessori art emphasizes process over product — the experience of painting matters more than what the final result looks like. Resist the urge to direct the child's creative choices. Your role is to demonstrate the technique (how to hold the brush, how to load paint, how to mix colors) and then step back. Watercolors teach patience because you must wait for layers to dry and work with the water's flow rather than against it. If the child is frustrated, suggest experimenting on a practice paper first. Display the finished painting — it validates the child's effort and builds confidence.

title: Gardening — Watering and Observing Seedlings
description: The child practices the daily routine of checking on planted seeds, watering when needed, and recording observations. This builds patience, responsibility, and early scientific observation skills.
instructions:
1. Go to the seed pots planted on Day 1.
2. 'First, let's observe. Look closely. Has anything changed?'
3. Touch the soil: 'Is it dry or damp? If it's dry on top, we need to water.'
4. Demonstrate gentle watering. 'Just a little — the soil should be moist, not flooded.'
5. 'Even though we can't SEE anything yet, the seed is working hard underground. Water is softening the seed coat.'
6. In the garden journal, draw what the pot looks like today. Write the date.
7. 'We'll check again tomorrow! Seeds take time — this is patience work.'

slides.heading: Gardening
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to be gardeners and take care of our little seeds. We'll learn how to give them a drink and watch them grow, just like you take care of your toys!

slides.setup_instructions: Bring the seed pots to the work area. Have the journal and watering can ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our gardening adventure! We have our special pots with the seeds, a little watering can, a special book to draw in, a pencil, and a magnifying glass to see tiny things. Ask a grown-up to help you find these so we can get started!

slides.text: 'Let's check on our seeds! Remember, we planted them two days ago. Let's be seed detectives today.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be seed detectives! We planted our seeds a few days ago, and now we get to check on them. Let's see if our little seeds are starting to wake up!

slides.text: 'First, LOOK. Do you see anything poking out of the soil? Not yet? That's okay — the seed is working underground!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's take a super close look at our seed pots. Do you see anything peeking out of the dirt yet? It's okay if you don't, because the seeds are busy working underground, getting ready to pop up!

slides.text: 'Now FEEL the soil gently with your finger. Is it dry or still damp? If it's dry, we water. If it's damp, the seed has enough.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's feel the dirt with our finger. Is it dry and dusty, or is it nice and damp? If it feels dry on top, our seed is thirsty and needs a drink of water.

slides.text: 'Water gently if needed. Let's draw what we see in our garden journal. Write today's date. Even if nothing has changed, that's an observation!'
slides.mascot_explanation: If the soil felt dry, we'll give our seed a little drink from the watering can, just a tiny bit so it's not too wet. Then, let's open our special garden book and draw what our pot looks like today, and write the date so we remember!

slides.prompt: Check each pot. Water if needed. In your journal, draw the pot and write: 'Day 3: Soil is ___. No sprout yet / I see ___.' Date your entry.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to check each seed pot! Feel the dirt, and if it's dry, give it a little water. Then, draw a picture of your pot in your journal and write down if the soil is wet or dry and if you see a sprout. Don't forget to write today's date!

slides.text: 'Scientists record observations every day, even when nothing seems to change. You are being a real scientist! We'll check again tomorrow.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child assess soil moisture, water appropriately, and record a dated observation?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job being a scientist today! You checked on your seeds, gave them water if they were thirsty, and drew a picture in your special book. Scientists watch things carefully, and you did that perfectly! We'll check again tomorrow to see if anything new has happened.

parent_notes: This seemingly simple activity teaches profound lessons. The child is learning delayed gratification — they planted seeds and must wait days or weeks to see results. Recording observations, even 'nothing changed,' teaches the scientific method. Montessori valued patience and the ability to wait as essential character traits. If the child is impatient, reassure them: 'The seed is busy underground. The shell is softening, the root is starting to grow. We just can't see it yet.' If you have bean seeds, sprouts may appear within 5-7 days, which keeps motivation high.

title: Long Vowel Patterns — Silent E (o_e)
description: Completing the magic e introduction with o_e words. The child now knows three silent e patterns (a_e, i_e, o_e) and can decode words like hope, home, bone, note, and code.
instructions:
1. Quick review: 'What does magic e do? Makes the vowel say its name! We know a_e (cape, lake) and i_e (bike, time).'
2. 'Today: the letter o! Watch.' Write 'hop.' Child reads: /h/-/o/-/p/ = hop.
3. Add e: 'hope!' 'The short /o/ changed to long /oh/ — o says its name!'
4. Practice pairs: hop/hope, not/note, cod/code, rob/robe, rod/rode.
5. Build o_e words: home, bone, cone, stone, phone, stove, those, woke.
6. Mixed review: read a_e, i_e, and o_e words mixed together.

slides.heading: The Magic E
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "The Magic E," and we're going to learn how the letter 'e' can be like a little magician for the letter 'o.' It helps the 'o' make a special long sound.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare o_e word pairs. Also have a few a_e and i_e words for the mixed review at the end.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some special tools for our game today! We have letter tiles that we can move around to make words, and we have cards with words on them. We'll use these to practice our magic 'e' words. Ask a grown-up to help you get them ready!

slides.text: 'We know two magic e patterns already! a_e makes /ay/ and i_e makes /eye/. Today the magic e works on the letter o!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned that 'a' and 'i' can say their names with a magic 'e'? Well, guess what? Today, the magic 'e' is going to help the letter 'o' say its name too! It's like a secret code we're learning.

slides.text: Build 'hop.' Child reads: 'hop.' Add e. 'Hope! The /o/ sound changed to /oh/ — the o says its name now!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's build a word together! We'll make the word "hop," like when you hop on one foot. Now, watch this magic! When we add an 'e' at the end, it turns "hop" into "hope," and the 'o' sound changes to "oh!" Isn't that neat?

slides.text: More pairs: not/note, cod/code, rob/robe, rod/rode. 'Each time, the e changes the short o to long o!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to play a word game with pairs of words. We'll read "not" and then add the magic 'e' to make "note." See how the 'o' sound changes from a short "o" to a long "oh"? We'll do this for a few more word pairs, like "cod" and "code."

slides.text: Build new o_e words: home, bone, cone, stone, woke, those. 'You're reading so many new words!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build some brand new words using our magic 'e' trick! We'll make words like "home," "bone," and "cone." You are becoming such a super reader, learning all these new words!

slides.prompt: Mixed challenge! Read these words — some are a_e, some are i_e, some are o_e: cake, bike, home, late, fine, stone, name, ride, hope. Sort them into three groups!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for a challenge! We have a mix of words here, some with the magic 'a_e,' some with magic 'i_e,' and some with our new magic 'o_e.' Your job is to read each word and then sort them into the right groups. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You now know three magic e patterns! a_e, i_e, and o_e. That's hundreds of new words you can read!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read o_e words and sort a mixed list of a_e, i_e, and o_e words correctly?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You learned how the magic 'e' helps 'o' say its name, and now you know three magic 'e' patterns. That means you can read so many more words, like "home" and "hope"! You're a reading superstar!

parent_notes: With three silent e patterns now in the child's toolkit, they can decode a huge number of English words. The mixed review at the end is important — it requires the child to look at the vowel AND the silent e together to determine the pronunciation. If the child struggles with sorting, focus on the vowel: 'What vowel do you see? A, I, or O? That's the group!' Note that u_e and e_e exist too but are less common and can be introduced later. The power of understanding the RULE rather than memorizing individual words is enormous — this is why Montessori phonics instruction is so effective.

title: Skip Counting Chain — Chain of 3
description: The child uses the short bead chain of 3 to count by threes. Each bar has 3 beads, and number arrows mark the skip counting sequence: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27.
instructions:
1. Bring out the short chain of 3 (nine bars of 3 beads connected by links).
2. Lay it in a straight line on the floor mat.
3. 'Each bar has 3 beads. Let's count by 3s!' Touch the end of each bar: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27.
4. Place number arrows at each bar.
5. 'Count by 3s with me — use the arrows to help: 3, 6, 9, 12...'
6. Remove arrows. Child places them independently.
7. 'Notice: 3, 6, 9 — that's 3 taken 3 times = 9. That's the square of 3!'

slides.heading: Bead Chain Counting
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It tells us we're going to learn a new way to count with our special bead chains. We're going to count by threes!

slides.setup_instructions: This chain is longer than the chain of 2! Make sure you have a long stretch of floor or table space.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the cool things we need for our counting game! We have a long chain made of little groups of beads, and special number signs. We also need a nice big space, like a floor mat, to lay everything out. Ask your grown-up to help you find them all!

slides.text: 'Today we have the chain of 3! Each bar has 3 beads. Let's stretch it out and count by 3s!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our bead chain ready! We're going to lay it out flat so we can see all the beads. This chain is made of groups of 3 beads, and we're going to count them in a special way today.

slides.text: Touch the end of each bar together: '3... 6... 9... 12... 15... 18... 21... 24... 27! That's a lot of 3s!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's count together! We'll touch the end of each group of 3 beads and say the next number. So we say 3, then 6, then 9, all the way to 27! That's a lot of counting!

slides.text: 'Let's place the arrows.' Place '3' at the first bar, '6' at the second, etc. 'The arrows show us the skip counting pattern.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these little number signs? They help us remember our special counting game. We're going to put one sign after each group of 3 beads to show what number we get to. It's like a treasure map for counting!

slides.text: 'Look: 3, 6, 9 — three 3s make 9. That's 3 times 3! We call 9 the SQUARE of 3.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look closely at the numbers we made! When we have three groups of 3 beads, it makes 9! It's like we took three steps of 3. We call 9 the "square" of 3, which is a fancy math word!

slides.prompt: Remove all arrows and place them back yourself. Count by 3s forward and backward. Can you say the sequence without looking? 3, 6, 9, 12...
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the teacher! Let's take off all the number signs and put them back in the right spot all by yourself. Then, try to say the counting numbers without even looking at the signs! You can do it!

slides.mastery_check: Can the child place arrows correctly on the chain of 3 and recite the skip counting sequence to at least 18?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You can count by threes all the way to 27! That means you know how to count 3, 6, 9, 12, and so on. You are super good at skip counting!

parent_notes: The chain of 3 is longer and more challenging than the chain of 2, but the process is identical. The child counts by 3s while touching each bar. The concept of the square (3 x 3 = 9) is introduced naturally — you can fold the chain into a square shape to show this visually. Don't require memorization of the sequence yet; the goal is familiarity through repeated physical counting. Some children enjoy singing or chanting the sequence, which aids memory. The bead chains eventually lead to understanding multiplication, squaring, and cubing — all through concrete, hands-on experience.

title: Spring Festivals Around the World — Holi and Nowruz
description: Learning about two spring celebrations from different cultures: Holi (the Hindu festival of colors) and Nowruz (Persian New Year). Children discover that many cultures celebrate the arrival of spring.
instructions:
1. 'People all over the world celebrate spring! Today we'll learn about two special festivals.'
2. Holi: Show pictures. 'In India, people throw colored powder and water at each other to celebrate spring! It's called Holi — the festival of colors.'
3. 'Holi celebrates the victory of good over evil and the arrival of spring. Everyone plays together — children and adults!'
4. Nowruz: 'In Iran and many other countries, Nowruz is the New Year! It happens on the first day of spring.'
5. 'Families set a special table called a Haft-Sin with 7 items that start with the letter S in Persian.'
6. Find India and Iran on the world map.
7. Art project: create a colorful Holi-inspired painting using chalk pastels or finger paints.
materials_needed: Pictures of Holi and Nowruz celebrations

slides.heading: Spring Festivals
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this, friend! It says "Spring Festivals," and we're going to learn about two super fun celebrations that happen when spring comes. It's going to be like a big party for spring!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather colorful pictures of both festivals. Have India and Iran located on the map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our fun! We have a big map to see where places are, colorful pictures to look at, and fun paints to make art. We also have a special smock to keep our clothes clean while we paint. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'When spring arrives, people everywhere celebrate! Today we'll learn about two amazing spring festivals from different parts of the world.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our teacher is telling us that when the flowers start to bloom and the weather gets warm, people all around the world get really happy! Today, we'll learn about two special parties that celebrate the wonderful arrival of spring.

slides.text: Show Holi pictures: 'This is HOLI — the Festival of Colors! In India, people throw bright colored powder at each other. Everyone gets covered in beautiful colors!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, this is so exciting! See these bright colors? This is for a festival called Holi in a country called India. People throw colorful powder and water at each other – it's like a big, happy color fight to celebrate spring!

slides.text: 'NOWRUZ is the Persian New Year. It's celebrated on the first day of spring! Families make a special table with 7 things that start with the letter S in the Persian language.'
slides.mascot_explanation: And this is for a special day called Nowruz, which is like a New Year party in a country called Iran. They set a table with seven special things to welcome the spring and the new year. It’s all about new beginnings!

slides.text: Find India and Iran on the map. 'These countries are far apart, but both celebrate spring! Spring means new life and new beginnings everywhere.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's find India and Iran on our big map! See how far apart they are? Even though they are in different places, both of these countries have special ways to celebrate when spring arrives. Spring is a happy time everywhere!

slides.prompt: Create a Holi-inspired artwork! Use chalk pastels or finger paints to make a colorful explosion of spring colors. Mix and blend as many colors as you can!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our own colorful art, just like the Holi festival! We're going to use these paints to make a big splash of all the happy spring colors. Mix them up and make a beautiful mess, just like a rainbow explosion!

slides.text: 'People all over the world celebrate spring in their own special ways. What's similar? Everyone is happy that warm weather and flowers are coming!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name both festivals and the countries where they are celebrated?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about these spring festivals! We learned that people in India celebrate Holi with colors, and people in Iran celebrate Nowruz for the New Year. It's so cool that everyone is happy for spring!

parent_notes: Montessori's cultural curriculum emphasizes respect for all peoples and customs. Learning about celebrations from other cultures builds empathy and broadens the child's worldview. Holi is visually stunning and children love the idea of throwing colors. Nowruz (literally 'new day') has been celebrated for over 3,000 years. The Haft-Sin table items (sprouts, garlic, apples, etc.) all symbolize aspects of life and renewal. You can extend this lesson by making your own 'spring table' with items that represent the season to your family. Emphasize what these celebrations have in common: joy, family, gratitude for spring.

title: Read-Aloud: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle
description: Reading this beloved classic about a caterpillar that eats through various foods before building a cocoon and emerging as a butterfly. Connects to the butterfly life cycle science lesson.
instructions:
1. Show the cover: 'We're learning about caterpillars and butterflies this week. This story is about a VERY hungry caterpillar!'
2. Read the story. On each food page, let the child count the items and poke fingers through the holes.
3. 'On Monday he ate through ONE apple. On Tuesday he ate through TWO pears...' Count together.
4. When the caterpillar eats junk food and gets a stomachache: 'What happened? Why did his tummy hurt?'
5. 'Then he ate one nice green leaf and felt much better.'
6. The cocoon and butterfly pages: 'This is what we learned about in science! Metamorphosis!'
7. Retell: 'What did the caterpillar eat on Wednesday?'
materials_needed: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It's the cover of our special book for today. It's called "The Very Hungry Caterpillar," and it's going to be so much fun to read together!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably where the child can see the pictures and touch the die-cut holes in the pages.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need our special book and a super comfy spot to read! Let's find a cozy place on the couch or on a soft rug so we can snuggle up and see all the pretty pictures.

slides.text: 'Remember what we learned about caterpillars in science? This is a story about a caterpillar with a BIG appetite!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about caterpillars in our science time? Well, this book is all about a super hungry caterpillar who loves to eat, eat, eat!

slides.text: Read with enthusiasm. Count the foods on each page: 'One apple, two pears, three plums...' Let the child poke fingers through the holes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to read our story! As we turn the pages, we'll count all the yummy foods the caterpillar eats, like one apple and two pears. And see these little holes? You can poke your finger right through them!

slides.text: At the junk food pages: 'Uh oh! A stomachache! What could help?' Then: 'One nice green leaf. He felt much better.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Uh oh! The caterpillar ate too much yucky food and got a tummy ache! But then he ate something healthy, and guess what? He felt all better!

slides.prompt: After reading, retell the story: 'What did he eat on each day? What happened at the end?' Can you act out the caterpillar eating and then becoming a butterfly?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend we are the caterpillar! Can you wiggle around like you're eating lots of food? Now, can you curl up like you're building a cozy home, and then stretch out like a beautiful butterfly?

slides.text: 'The caterpillar ate, grew, built a cocoon, and became a beautiful butterfly — just like the real butterflies we're studying!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sequence the days and foods and connect the story to the real butterfly life cycle?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job with our story! Remember how the caterpillar turned into a butterfly? That's just like the real butterflies we are learning about in science!

parent_notes: Even if your child has heard this story many times, reading it now — while studying the butterfly life cycle — gives it new meaning. The counting element (1 apple, 2 pears, 3 plums, 4 strawberries, 5 oranges) reinforces number sequence. The healthy eating message (junk food causes a stomachache, a green leaf helps) is gentle but clear. Note that Eric Carle uses 'cocoon' rather than the scientifically accurate 'chrysalis' for butterflies — you can gently mention this distinction: 'In the story it's called a cocoon, but scientists call a butterfly's special covering a chrysalis.'

title: Geometric Cabinet — Curved Figures Drawer
description: The child works with the geometric cabinet's curved figures drawer, tracing and naming the circle, ellipse, oval, and curvilinear triangle. Develops visual discrimination and vocabulary for curved shapes.
instructions:
1. Take out the curved figures drawer from the geometric cabinet.
2. Remove the circle inset. Trace the frame (outside), then the inset (inside) with two fingers.
3. 'This is a circle. It curves the same amount all the way around.'
4. Remove the ellipse: 'This is an ellipse. It's like a stretched circle — longer in one direction.'
5. Remove the oval: 'This is an oval. It looks like an egg — one end is slightly bigger.'
6. Remove the curvilinear triangle: 'This shape has three curved sides!'
7. Three-period lesson for the names.
8. Child traces each shape and matches insets to frames.
materials_needed: Paper and colored pencils for tracing (optional)

slides.heading: Geometric Cabinet
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is a special box with lots of cool shapes inside. We're going to learn about shapes that are round and bendy, like a bouncy ball!

items: Optional: paper and colored pencils for tracing
slides.setup_instructions: Place the drawer on the mat. The child should be able to reach all insets easily.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready for our shape adventure! We need this special drawer with all the curved shapes, and this mat to put it on. If you want, you can also get some paper and crayons to draw the shapes later!

slides.text: 'Today we're exploring shapes with CURVES — no straight lines at all! Let's start with one you know.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to find shapes that don't have any straight lines, only wiggly, curvy ones. Let's start with a shape you probably already know really well!

slides.text: Remove the circle: 'Trace around the frame, then around the inset. Feel how it curves the same amount everywhere? This is a CIRCLE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's take out the circle shape. Feel how it goes round and round without any corners? You can trace the outside part and then the inside part with your fingers. This is a circle!

slides.text: Ellipse: 'This looks like a circle that got stretched! It's called an ELLIPSE. Trace it — feel how it's longer one way?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this next shape! It's like a circle that got a little bit squished, or stretched out. We call this an ellipse. Trace it with your fingers and feel how it's longer in one way.

slides.text: Oval: 'An OVAL looks like an egg. See how one end is a little pointier?' Curvilinear triangle: 'Three CURVED sides!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are two more fun shapes! This one looks like a yummy egg, and it's called an oval. And this shape has three sides, but they are all curved, not straight lines!

slides.prompt: Three-period lesson: 'Show me the ellipse. Show me the oval. Which one is this?' Then trace each shape on paper with a colored pencil.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's play a game with the shapes! Can you point to the ellipse? Can you show me the oval? Great job finding them! Now you can trace them on your paper with your crayons if you like.

slides.text: 'You know four curved shapes now: circle, ellipse, oval, and curvilinear triangle. Look for these shapes in the world around you!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and trace all four curved figures and distinguish the ellipse from the oval?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job learning all the curved shapes today! You know the circle, the ellipse, the oval, and the curvy triangle. Keep looking for these shapes everywhere you go!

parent_notes: The geometric cabinet is a key Montessori sensorial material. The curved figures drawer helps the child see subtle differences between similar shapes. The distinction between ellipse and oval is surprisingly nuanced — an ellipse is symmetrical on both axes, while an oval is only symmetrical on one (like an egg, wider at one end). Children don't need to articulate this mathematically; they absorb the difference through tracing and comparing. The two-finger tracing technique develops the light touch needed for writing while building shape recognition. If you don't have the geometric cabinet, you can make cardboard insets of these shapes.

title: Reading Longer Stories — Decodable Readers with Silent E
description: The child reads a short decodable story that includes silent e words alongside CVC words. This puts the new phonics pattern into context and builds reading fluency and comprehension.
instructions:
1. Choose a decodable reader that features a_e, i_e, and o_e words (or write a short story together).
2. Example text: 'Jake rode his bike to the lake. He came at five. Kate made a cake. They ate by the stone.'
3. Child reads the story aloud. Help with any difficult words by reminding: 'Is there a magic e?'
4. After reading, ask comprehension questions: 'Where did Jake ride? What did Kate make?'
5. Read the story a second time for fluency.
6. 'Can you find all the magic e words in the story?' Child circles or points to them.
materials_needed: Decodable reader with silent e words

slides.heading: Reading Practice
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to do some super fun reading practice today with special words called "magic E" words. It's like a secret code in our reading!

items: Decodable reader or printed story with silent e words
slides.setup_instructions: Select or print a decodable story that features silent e words mixed with CVC words. The story should be 4-8 sentences long.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story, we need a few things. We need our special reading book with the magic E words, a mat to keep our work tidy, and a pencil for pointing and writing. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these for our reading adventure?

slides.text: 'You've learned the magic e patterns this week. Now let's read a STORY that uses those words! Stories are what reading is all about.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our first step! We've learned all about those tricky magic E words, and now we get to use them in a real story. Reading stories is one of the most exciting parts of learning to read!

slides.text: Child reads the story aloud. If they hesitate on a word: 'Look carefully. Do you see an e at the end? What does that tell you?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, it's your turn to read! Take your time and read the story out loud. If you get stuck on a word, just look closely – sometimes that little 'e' at the end is like magic and changes the sound of the letter before it!

slides.text: After reading: 'Tell me what happened in the story. Who are the characters? What did they do?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job reading! Now, tell me, what was this story all about? Who were the characters, and what did they do in their adventure?

slides.text: 'Now let's be word detectives! Can you find all the magic e words in the story? Point to each one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's be word detectives now! Can you find all the special "magic E" words in the story? Point to each one you see, just like you're finding hidden treasure!

slides.prompt: Read the story two more times. Each time, try to read a little more smoothly. Then find and list all the silent e words you see.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to read the story one more time, and this time, let's try to read it extra smoothly, like a fast little river. After that, we'll be word detectives again and find all those magic E words!

slides.text: 'You just read a whole story with magic e words! The more you read, the easier it gets.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read the decodable story with reasonable fluency and answer 2-3 comprehension questions?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read a whole story all by yourself using those magic E words. Every time you read, you get even better and stronger at reading, just like a superhero!

parent_notes: Reading decodable stories is the bridge between phonics lessons and real reading. The child sees the patterns they've learned in meaningful context. If you don't have a commercial decodable reader, write a simple story using a_e, i_e, and o_e words mixed with CVC words the child already knows. Keep sentences short and the story simple but interesting. Reading the same story multiple times builds fluency — each re-reading is smoother and more confident. Comprehension questions ensure the child is reading for meaning, not just decoding. Celebrate their progress: 'You're reading stories now!'

title: Stamp Game Multiplication — Two-Digit Numbers
description: Extending stamp game multiplication to two-digit numbers. The child builds a two-digit number multiple times and combines the results, practicing exchange when units exceed 10.
instructions:
1. 'Remember multiplication? Taking a number many times. Today we'll multiply bigger numbers!'
2. Problem: 12 taken 3 times (12 x 3).
3. Build 12 three times on the stamp game: each group has 1 blue ten stamp and 2 green unit stamps.
4. Combine all the ten stamps: 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 tens.
5. Combine all the unit stamps: 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 units.
6. Result: 36! Write: 12 x 3 = 36.
7. Try 14 x 2: build 14 twice. 1+1 = 2 tens, 4+4 = 8 units = 28.
8. Try 13 x 3: 3 tens + 9 units = 39.
materials_needed: Paper and pencil for recording equations

slides.heading: Stamp Game Multiplication
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we get to play a super fun math game with stamps. We're going to learn how to take bigger numbers and count them lots of times, like a super-duper math explorer!

slides.setup_instructions: Set out the stamp game. Have enough space for building multiple groups. Paper ready for recording.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for our stamp adventure, we need a few special things. We have our "stamp game" with colorful stamps, a special mat to build on, and paper and a pencil to write down our amazing discoveries. Ask a grown-up to help you get these ready so we can start!

slides.text: 'You've been multiplying small numbers. Now let's try BIGGER numbers! 12 taken 3 times. That means we build 12 THREE times.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about counting? Well, now we get to do something even cooler! We're going to learn how to take a number, like 12, and count it not just one time, but three whole times! It's like having three birthday cakes instead of just one!

slides.text: Build first group: 1 blue ten stamp, 2 green unit stamps. 'That's 12.' Build second and third groups the same way.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make our first group of 12. We'll use one blue stamp for the "ten" and two green stamps for the "ones." Now, we need to make two more groups just like this one, so we have three groups of 12 all together!

slides.text: 'Now combine! How many tens? 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 tens. How many units? 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 units. 36!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! Now let's count all our blue "ten" stamps – one, two, three! And let's count all our green "one" stamps – one, two, three, four, five, six! So, three tens and six ones make the number 36!

slides.text: Write: 12 x 3 = 36. 'Let's try another: 14 taken 2 times.' Build, combine, record.
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job building 12 three times to get 36! Now, let's write it down like real mathematicians: 12 times 3 equals 36. Let's try another one together, like 14 taken two times!

slides.prompt: Solve these with the stamp game: 11 x 4, 15 x 2, 13 x 3. Build each group, combine, and write the equation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the stamp game master! Let's build 11 four times, then 15 two times, and then 13 three times. Remember to count your tens and then your ones, and write down the answer for each one. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You can multiply two-digit numbers! The stamp game helps us see what happens when we take a number many times.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build a two-digit number multiple times, combine the stamps correctly, and state the product?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a multiplication superstar! You learned how to take bigger numbers and count them many times using our special stamps. It was so cool to see you build the numbers and figure out the answers all by yourself!

parent_notes: Moving to two-digit multiplication is exciting because the child works with both tens and units simultaneously. The stamp game makes this manageable — each category (tens, units) is combined separately. At this stage, we're choosing problems where units don't exceed 9 when combined (to avoid exchange). Once the child is comfortable, you can introduce problems requiring exchange (like 16 x 2, where 6+6=12 units requires exchanging 10 units for 1 ten). The key principle: multiplication is repeated addition, and the stamp game makes this visible and concrete.

title: Life Cycle of a Butterfly — Chrysalis Stage
description: Continuing the butterfly life cycle study with the chrysalis (pupa) stage. The child learns that the caterpillar forms a chrysalis and undergoes metamorphosis — a complete transformation — inside.
instructions:
1. Review: 'What have we learned so far? Egg, then caterpillar. The caterpillar eats and grows. What happens next?'
2. 'When the caterpillar is big enough, something amazing happens. It attaches itself to a branch and forms a hard shell called a CHRYSALIS.'
3. Show pictures of a chrysalis. 'It might look like nothing is happening, but INSIDE, the caterpillar is completely changing!'
4. 'This change is called METAMORPHOSIS. The caterpillar's body breaks down and rebuilds into something completely new.'
5. 'It's like the greatest magic trick in nature — a crawling caterpillar becomes a flying butterfly!'
6. Child draws the chrysalis stage in their science journal and labels it.
7. Update the life cycle diagram: egg, caterpillar, chrysalis.
materials_needed: Life cycle diagram from previous lesson

slides.heading: Life Cycle of a Butterfly
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Life Cycle of a Butterfly" and talks about something called the "Chrysalis." That's a super important part of how a butterfly grows!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather pictures showing the caterpillar attaching and forming a chrysalis. Have the journal with previous drawings ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, friend, let's get our special tools ready for our butterfly adventure! We have some pretty pictures of chrysalises, our science notebook where we draw, some colorful pencils, and a chart showing the butterfly's growing-up steps. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: 'Remember our caterpillar? It ate and ate and grew. When it's finally big enough, it's ready for the next step. Something incredible!'
